review: We use Plex media player and Netflix for 90% of our TV time. This thing is a perfect fit for our house. I bought 4 and put one in each room. Basically, you take any mobile device (iPad, iPod, smart phone, windows tablet, etc) and the devices have apps. The apps listed on Chromecast website will have a "wireless icon" at the top for casting. You touch that icon and select a chromecast, then click play and BAM! HD streaming content from your media server or from a service like Netflix, Hulu, etc.Setup was also easy. Basically the Chromecast has its own wireless card, so plug it into the TV and USB power. You goto your PC or Mac computer or laptop, and visit the Chromecast URL. You install the Chromecast application to your computer which finds "available Chromecasts that need setup". You follow the easy 3-4 simple steps of connecting to the Chromecast, then connecting your Chromecast to your home wireless network. Then any mobile device on your wireless network can stream to any Chromecast. Took me about 15 minutes to setup the first one, and like 5 minutes to setup the second.

review: Since I already have a Roku player, the main reason I bought te Chromecast  was to view video streams on my TV that are not available through Hulu, Amazon prime, Netflix etc. I have mixed feelings about its performance. Youtube videos play well and it's nice not having to run an HDMI cable from my laptop to TV. However streaming internet video is a big disappointment. I tried watching Olympic highlights and it was a bust. Lots of lag and frozen images.The Google Chromecast help menus basically put the blame on my laptop. Yet, the streaming is perfectly fine on my PC.I think what I really need is just something that will emulate an HDMI cable. If I can find this, I'd consider returning this unit as it doesn't live up to my expectations.However, if your intent is to use it to watch Youtube videos or to view Chromecast friendly programs, perhaps it's a good, inexpensive solution.
